channel.title: Funny – Syntactically Correct
channel.description: Amit Schreiber's Blog | הבלוג של עמית שרייבר

item.title: Trying Google’s Voice Search
item.dc:creator: Amit Schreiber
item.description:
Here’s what I got trying to say “Amit Schreiber” into Google’s Voice Search using my netbook and Google Chrome: sperm tribe sure I burn ami schreiber what the f*** chile I’m yours driver tommy shaw rugs how many shriver short send me to a boot striper Oh, well… I guess it goes through a relevance …

Continue reading "Trying Google’s Voice Search"
item.content:encoded:
Here’s what I got trying to say “Amit Schreiber” into Google’s Voice Search using my netbook and Google Chrome:

  1. sperm tribe
  2. sure I burn
  3. ami schreiber what the f***
  4. chile
  5. I’m yours driver
  6. tommy shaw rugs
  7. how many shriver
  8. short
  9. send me to a boot
  10. striper

Oh, well… I guess it goes through a relevance engine and I’m just not that famous enough. Yet! :)

item.title: Forgotten Experiences
item.dc:creator: Amit Schreiber
item.description:
Yesterday I called a friend of mine who is visiting from the US and is staying at her parents’ place. My mind struggled for 2 seconds before I remembered how to say “may I speak with…” It’s been years since I’ve uttered this request. And today my father called to tell me about an interesting …

Continue reading "Forgotten Experiences"
item.content:encoded:
Yesterday I called a friend of mine who is visiting from the US and is staying at her parents’ place. My mind struggled for 2 seconds before I remembered how to say “may I speak with…” It’s been years since I’ve uttered this request.

And today my father called to tell me about an interesting article he saw and thought I would like to read. I immediately said “email me the link” and he replied “I’m reading it on the hard copy.” Again… took me a few seconds to realize what he was referring to.

item.title: Google Probably Knows Everything About Me…
item.dc:creator: Amit Schreiber
item.description: … but then why do I get Venus women’s razor ads on YouTube? Maybe it’s a “knowing the future” kind of thing. EDIT: OK, this is not funny. Now I got an Always pads ad. What the hell, Google?
item.content:encoded:
… but then why do I get Venus women’s razor ads on YouTube?

Maybe it’s a “knowing the future” kind of thing.

EDIT: OK, this is not funny. Now I got an Always pads ad. What the hell, Google?

item.title: Programmers Who Care About The Environment…
item.dc:creator: Amit Schreiber
item.description: … don’t use interpreted languages. You know… because of the extra CPU cycles. I had to get it out. Sorry.
item.content:encoded:
… don’t use interpreted languages.

You know… because of the extra CPU cycles.

I had to get it out.

Sorry.

item.title: You Know You’ve Been Using Your Smartphone For A While When…
item.dc:creator: Amit Schreiber
item.description: …. it takes you a second to realize you have to physically press down a resistive touchscreen to get a response. (either that or I’m just getting old)
item.content:encoded:
…. it takes you a second to realize you have to physically press down a resistive touchscreen to get a response.

(either that or I’m just getting old)

item.title: אסוס של בעברית התקנה
item.dc:creator: Amit Schreiber
item.description: אני בטוח שהם השתמשו במכונה תרגום. מי שעוד הפתיעו הם מיקרוסופט שקראו ל- Sleep שינה ול- Hibernation מצב שינה. לך תסביר למישהו שלא מכיר את ההבדלים בין השניים. אני חושב שאיך שתרגמו מישהו הלך וכתב את ההסבר הזה.
item.content:encoded:
אני בטוח שהם השתמשו במכונה תרגום.

מי שעוד הפתיעו הם מיקרוסופט שקראו ל- Sleep שינה ול- Hibernation מצב שינה. לך תסביר למישהו שלא מכיר את ההבדלים בין השניים. אני חושב שאיך שתרגמו מישהו הלך וכתב את ההסבר הזה.

item.title: The Israeli Movie Naming Gods Screwed Me
item.dc:creator: Amit Schreiber
item.description:
Yesterday a friend invited me to see a movie after work. The movie’s name in Israel is “The Prophecy.” As we’re waiting for the movie to start he asks me “so when was the last time you went to the movies?” I said it was on the trip, where I saw “Watchmen” and another movie …

Continue reading "The Israeli Movie Naming Gods Screwed Me"
item.content:encoded:
Yesterday a friend invited me to see a movie after work. The movie’s name in Israel is “The Prophecy.” As we’re waiting for the movie to start he asks me “so when was the last time you went to the movies?” I said it was on the trip, where I saw “Watchmen” and another movie I forgot. When the first frame of the movie showed on screen I said to him “I remember which movie it was. This one.”

Turns out the movie naming gods in Israel decided to translate “Knowing”, which I saw on day 78 of the trip, to “The Prophecy.” And on top of that it’s a mystery movie. So you can imagine my surprise when the kid says “I see dead people” the second time around.

Just kidding. The kid dies about half way through the movie.

item.title: My Oldest Email Messages
item.dc:creator: Amit Schreiber
item.description:
ISP (from my local mail archive at home): Date: February 1, 1998 Subject: a Vocaltec Internet Phone license I got as a gift from my now-deceased Canadian relative. Using this software we had a lot of enjoyable video conversations over the Internet. I also found a lot of stories he sent me over time. Hotmail: …

Continue reading "My Oldest Email Messages"
item.content:encoded:
• ISP (from my local mail archive at home):
    • Date: February 1, 1998
    • Subject: a Vocaltec Internet Phone license I got as a gift from my now-deceased Canadian relative. Using this software we had a lot of enjoyable video conversations over the Internet. I also found a lot of stories he sent me over time.
  • Hotmail:
    • Date: March 16, 1999
    • Subject: registration confirmation from Serials 99. I believe I can still use it :)
  • Yahoo!:
    • Date: October 2, 2003
    • Subject: a message from an old acquaintance who found me online. This is from the short period of time in my life when I tried to switch from Hotmail to Yahoo! Mail. Once I got a Gmail account, I ditched Yahoo! Mail for it.
  • Gmail:
    • Date: August 11, 2004
    • Subject: “welcome to Gmail” message explaining how Gmail is different

I’m an Internet dinosaur.
